content: This has been true in my experience as well. I absolutely write code, and I have the entire 10+ year history of Chef. Most of what I write is prototypes, to help me understand the technology landscape and the market. Occasionally those prototypes turn in to full R&D — our Habitat project is an example of that. The most important part is remembering that as a CTO, the one thing everyone agrees on is that your role is to help the business understand where technology is going, and how to avoid pitfalls. Those needs will trump whatever desire you have for coding most of the time — so you have to stay out of the critical path most of the time. Nice post!
